newsitem.title: USA: Occidental president says trading boosted revs - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Occidental president says trading boosted revs - WSJ.

text.p: Occidental Petroleum Corp's president acknowledged the company boosted revenue through money-losing crude oil trading partly in order to make its oil and natural gas operations look larger, the Wall Street Journal said in Wednesday's electronic edition.
According to Occidental's annual report, the company's crude-oil trading totaled about $1 billion in 1995 and 1996 and about $800 million in 1994, the newspaper said.
This equalled about one-third of Occidental's oil and natural gas revenues and was included in reported sales, the Journal said.

Occidental President and Senior Operating Officer Dale Laurence was quoted in the paper as saying in an interview part of the company's aim was to make "our oil and (natural) gas businesses appear to be a larger entity," as well as helping the company understand commodity market conditions.
The Journal said Laurence acknowledged trades were partly meant to help Occidental deal with other companies in the industry by improving "the overall cosmetics of the company."
The paper said one internal memo indicated from 1990 to 1993, Occidental incurred nearly $10 million in total losses from what the document called "speculative" crude trades.
Occidental spokesmen were quoted as saying looses since 1993 were much lower.
According to internal documents and company officials, the trading made Occidental's petroleum operations look more robust in both good and less prosperous times, the paper said.
Officials were also quoted as saying they thought the trading complied with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission disclosure rules.
